com.stormpath.sdk.phone

Class Phones

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.stormpath.sdk.phone.Phones

  • public final class Phones
extends Object
    Static utility/helper methods for working with Phone resources. Most methods are factory methods used for forming Phone-specific fluent DSL queries. For example: 
     Phones.where(Phones.name().containsIgnoreCase("Foo"))
     .and(Phones.status().eq(PhoneStatus.ENABLED))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccount()
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    or, if using static imports: 
     import static com.stormpath.sdk.phone.Phones.*;

 ...

 where(name().containsIgnoreCase("Foo"))
     .and(status().eq(PhoneStatus.ENABLED))
     .orderByName().descending()
     .withAccount()
     .offsetBy(50)
     .limitTo(25));
    Since:
    1.1.0

    • Method Detail

      • options

        public static PhoneOptions<PhoneOptions> options()
        Returns a new PhoneOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Phones are retrieved.
        Returns:
        a new PhoneOptions instance, used to customize how one or more Phones are retrieved.

      • criteria

        public static PhoneCriteria criteria()
        Returns a new PhoneCriteria instance to use to formulate a Phone query.

        Note that it is usually more common to use the where method instead of this one as the where method usually lends to better readability. For example: 

         Phones.criteria().add(Phones.name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        versus: 
         Phones.where(Phones.name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        or when using static imports: 
         where(name().eqIgnoreCase("Foo"))...
        While all three statements are equivalent, the second and third examples are shorter and probably more readable.
        Returns:
        a new PhoneCriteria instance to use to formulate a Phone query.

      • where

        public static PhoneCriteria where(Criterion criterion)
        Creates a new PhoneCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.
        Returns:
        a new PhoneCriteria instance using the specified criterion as the first query condition.

      • name

        public static StringExpressionFactory name()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone name property, to be used to construct a name Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.name().startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a name-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory nameExpressionFactory = Phones.name();
 Criterion nameStartsWithFoo = nameExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(nameStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new name-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • number

        public static StringExpressionFactory number()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone number property, to be used to construct a number Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.number().startsWithIgnoreCase("201");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a number-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory numberExpressionFactory = Phones.number();
 Criterion numberStartsWithFoo = numberExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(nameStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new number-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • description

        public static StringExpressionFactory description()
        Creates a new StringExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone description property, to be used to construct a description Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.description().startsWithIgnoreCase("This is a description");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's startsWithIgnoreCase("foo") method. This produces a description-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory descriptionExpressionFactory = Phones.description();
 Criterion descriptionStartsWithFoo = descriptionExpressionFactory.startsWithIgnoreCase("foo");
 criteria.add(descriptionStartsWithFoo);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new number-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • status

        public static EqualsExpressionFactory status()
        Creates a new EqualsExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone status property, to be used to construct a status Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.status().eq(PhoneStatus.ENABLED);
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eq() method. This produces a status-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory statusExpressionFactory = Phones.status();
 Criterion statusEqualsEnabled = statusExpressionFactory.eq(PhoneStatus.ENABLED);
 criteria.add(statusEqualsEnabled);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new status-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • verificationStatus

        public static EqualsExpressionFactory verificationStatus()
        Creates a new EqualsExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone verificationStatus property, to be used to construct a status Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.verificationStatus().eq(PhoneVerificationStatus.VERIFIED);
        The above example invokes the returned factory's eq() method. This produces a verificationStatus-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). For example, the following code is equivalent: 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 StringExpressionFactory statusExpressionFactory = Phones.verificationStatus();
 Criterion verificationStatusEqualsEnabled = verificationStatusExpressionFactory.eq(PhoneVerificationStatus.VERIFIED);
 criteria.add(verificationStatusEqualsEnabled);
        The first code example is clearly more succinct and readable.
        Returns:
        a new verificationStatus-specific StringExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • createdAt

        public static DateExpressionFactory createdAt()
        Creates a new DateExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone createdAt property, to be used to construct a createdAt Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.createdAt().matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]")) method. This produces a createdAt-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). 
         For example, the following code is equivalent:
 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 DateExpressionFactory createdAt = Phones.createdAt();
 Criterion createdAtMatches = createdAt.matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]");
 criteria.add(createdAtMatches);
        Returns:
        a new createdAt-specific DateExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.

      • modifiedAt

        public static DateExpressionFactory modifiedAt()
        Creates a new DateExpressionFactory instance reflecting the Phone modifiedAt property, to be used to construct a modifiedAt Criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query. For example: 
         Phones.where(Phones.modifiedAt().matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]");
        The above example invokes the returned factory's matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]")) method. This produces a modifiedAt-specific Criterion which is added to the criteria query (via the where method). 
         For example, the following code is equivalent:
 
         PhoneCriteria criteria = Phones.criteria();
 DateExpressionFactory createdAt = Phones.modifiedAt();
 Criterion modifiedAtMatches = modifiedAt.matches("[,2014-04-05T12:00:00]");
 criteria.add(modifiedAtMatches);
        Returns:
        a new modifiedAt-specific DateExpressionFactory instance, to be used to construct a criterion when building an PhoneCriteria query.
        Since:
        1.0.RC4.6

      • newCreateRequestFor

        public static CreatePhoneRequestBuilder newCreateRequestFor(Phone phone)
        Creates a new createPhoneRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Phone instance. The builder can be used to customize any creation request options as necessary.
        Parameters:
        phone - the phone to create a new record for within Stormpath
        Returns:
        a new createPhoneRequestBuilder instance reflecting the specified Phone instance.
        Since:
        1.1.0
        See Also:
        Account.createPhone(CreatePhoneRequest)
